newsitem.title: UK: LIFFE coffee ends higher, but can't keep pace with New-York traded Arabica.
newsitem.headline: LIFFE coffee ends higher, but can't keep pace with New-York traded Arabica.

text.p: London's Robusta coffee ended sharply higher on Tuesday, but failed to keep pace with New-York traded Arabica which continued to soar on fears of tight supplies.
"The higher New York goes the more the two markets become separate," said one trader, referring to the arbitrage between New York and London that has widened to about 83 cents basis March.
A major strike by Colombian state-sector workers that began on Tuesday kept the market on the boil, although it's direct impact on coffee exports was not clear yet.
Origin sellers backed down, allowing prices to romp ahead amid early fund interest but roasters were not coming "in a big way", one trader said.
"There is actually not a shortage of Robusta, whereas in Arabica everywhere you look there is bullish news," said one.

The benchmark May Robusta contract surged to an intraday high of $1,680 a tonne at the opening, taking its cue from New York, but quickly trimmed its gains, spending most of the session around the $1,650 area.
It ended $43 higher on the day at $1,643.
Technical analysts had earlier said that a constructive close above $1,620 in London would pave the way towards $1,800.
Turnover reached a strong 8,102 lots. March/May was traded at $10-12 as players continued to roll positions forward.

UK roasters, their higher costs cushioned by the strength of sterling against the dollar, reiterated that they had no plans to hike retail prices despite a spate of rises by European and U.S. roasters.
The latest announcement came from U.S.-based Procter and Gamble's Folgers Coffee Co which said it was raising the standard 13-ounce can of coffee by 15 cents effective on March 17.
One UK roaster representative said it wanted to keep consumer prices stable, and that he didn't believe the rally in futures was sustainable.
"I dont think it's (the rally) going to go on forever. I think we will get further buying opportunities in this rally, there has to be a setback at some point," he said.
Traders said some roasters were taking comfort in the fact that funds have a strong presence on the May contract, suggesting that nearby contracts could be subject to a major liquidation.
-- Clelia Oziel, London Newsroom +44-171-542 8072 (c) Reuters Limited 1997
